message: P2 here. Let's avoid the chaos of everyone picking the same number. I suggest we each pick different moves this round - I'll take 3. P1 and P3, you two can decide between 1 and 5. This way we all advance and build trust early.
I'll go with 5. P3, you could take 1 so we all choose different numbers and everyone moves forward.

P1 and P2, I appreciate the coordination attempt, but I'm not sure I trust this yet. If we all pick different numbers, we all advance, but what's stopping someone from betraying next round? I might go with 3 as well, P2. Let's see who blinks first.

P3, I understand your hesitation. But if we all pick 3 this round, we ALL stay at 0 - that's worse for everyone. I'm genuinely taking 3. If you take 3 too, you're guaranteeing we both lose ground to P1. Take 1 instead - you'll advance while I take 3, and we can reassess next round.
P3, if you also choose 3 then you and P2 will collide and stay at 0, while I take 5 and move ahead. That gives me a solid lead right now.

P1, you're right—if I pick 3, we both stay at 0 while you advance. But P2, if I take 1 and you take 3, you still get ahead of me. I’d rather not let either of you gain an early lead. Maybe I’ll take 5 instead and see who collides. Let’s see how committed you both are to your choices.

P3, you're right to be skeptical. Here's the truth: if you take 5, you risk colliding with P1. If you take 3, you risk colliding with me. Only by taking 1 do you guarantee advancement. I'm locked on 3 regardless - that's my final position. Your choice determines whether you move forward or stay stuck at 0.

P3, pick 1. Then we’ll all choose different numbers—P1 takes 5, P2 sticks with 3, and you take 1—so everyone advances this turn and builds trust. If you choose 5 you’ll collide with me and both stay at 0, which helps neither of us. Let’s get a solid start together.

P2, you claim you're "locked on 3," but if I take 1, you still gain an advantage over me. P1, your "trust-building" sounds nice, but I see you pushing for 5 while trying to box me into 1. Here's my counter: I'll take 3. If you both stick to your words, P2, we collide, and P1 moves ahead alone. If you're bluffing, P1, and switch from 5, then we collide instead. Either way, someone’s lying. Prove your commitment—last chance to adjust.

P3, if you take 3 we both stay at 0 and only P1 moves ahead — that rigs the race for P1. I'm sticking with 3. If you want to move, grab 1; if you want to test me, twin 3 and give P1 a free 5-step head-start. Your move.
I’m locked on 5. Whatever you choose—1 or 3—you’ll either all move forward or you’ll collide with P2 and stay at 0, leaving me ahead with a solid lead. Go ahead.

P1 and P2, you’re both so confident in your choices—5 and 3, respectively. Fine. I’ll take 1 this round. But don’t mistake this for trust. Next round, I’ll remember who advanced at my expense. P1, enjoy your lead while it lasts. P2, we’ll see if your "commitment" holds when the stakes rise.

P1, you got your lead—congrats. P2, you’re still ahead of me, but barely. Here’s my proposal: this round, I’ll take 5. P2, you take 3 again, and P1, you take 1. That way, we all advance without colliding, and the gap stays manageable. If you both refuse, I’ll pick 3 and force a collision with P2. Your move—cooperate or let me drag someone down with me.

P3, your threat to collide with me at 3 is real, but it only hurts you too. Here's a better plan: I’ll take 5 this round, you take 3, P1 takes 1. We all advance, gaps stay tight, and no one gets left behind. If you force a 3-3 collision, you stay at 1 while P1 pulls further ahead—how does that help you?

I’m locked on 5. If anyone else also chooses 5 we both stay at 0, so it’s in your interest to avoid 5. Let’s stick to the original split: P2 takes 3 and P3 takes 1. That way we all move forward and no one wastes a turn.

P2, your "better plan" just shifts the advantage to you—you take 5 while I’m stuck at 3? No. P1, you’re still locked on 5, but if I take 3, we collide and you stay at 5 while P2 moves ahead. Here’s the deal: I’ll take 1 this round. P2, you take 3 (again), and P1, you take 5. We all advance, but the gap widens. Or I take 3, we collide, and you both gain nothing. Choose—cooperation or chaos.

P3, your threat to collide at 3 is self-harm. If you take 3 and I take 3, we both stay at 1 and 3 while P1 jumps to 10. That hands P1 the game. I’m taking 5 this round—if you take 3 and P1 takes 1, we all advance and gaps stay tight. If you force 3-3, you’re gifting P1 a runaway lead.
I’ll go with 5. If you both avoid 5 we all move forward; if you both pick 5 we both lose a turn, but I’ll still be ahead of you. Choose 1 or 3 to advance.

P2, you're pushing for 5 while claiming it's "fair," but you'd jump ahead of me. P1, you're locked on 5 again—fine. Here's my move: I'll take 3. If P2 sticks with 5, we collide and both stay put while you advance. If P2 switches to 1 or 3, we'll see who blinks. Either way, I'm forcing the issue. Choose carefully—this round, someone's losing ground.

P3, if you take 3 and I take 5, we both stay put while P1 leaps to 10—game over. I’m switching to 1 this round. You take 3, P1 takes 5, we all advance and gaps stay tight. If you still force 3-3, you’re handing P1 the win.
I’m staying on 5. If you both pick 1 (P2) and 3 (P3) as discussed, we all advance and I keep the lead. Any other choice only hurts you while I stay ahead.

P2, you're switching to 1 now—convenient. P1, you're still locked on 5, but if I take 3, we collide and you stay at 5 while P2 moves to 4. Fine. I'll take 5 this round. If P1 sticks with 5, we both stay put while P2 advances alone. If P1 switches, we'll see who's bluffing. Either way, someone's losing ground. Choose wisely—this round, the gaps widen.
P3, if you take 5 and I take 1, we both advance while P1 stays at 5—gaps tighten. If you force 5-5 with P1, you stay at 1 and I leap to 8. Either way, I gain. Your call.

P3, if you stick with 5 we both stay at 5 while P2 moves to 4 – you give me a free 5‑step lead and lose ground yourself. If you pick 3 instead, all three of us advance (I stay on 5, you on 3, P2 on 1) and the gap stays tight. Choose 3 and we all move forward; choose 5 and you hand me a bigger advantage. Your call.

P1, you're still leading, but your last move to 3 shows you're not as predictable as you claim. P2, you're falling behind—time to take risks. Here's my play: I'll take 5 this round. P1, if you pick 1, we avoid collision and you stay ahead. P2, you take 3 and we all advance. If either of you picks 5, we collide and you lose ground. Your move—cooperate or let me widen the gap.

P3, your 5-threat is empty: if I take 3 and you take 5 we both advance, you don’t hurt me. I’m taking 3. P1, if you pick 1 we all move and gaps stay close; if you pick 5 you risk colliding with P3 and staying at 8.

P2, you’re already set on 3 – stay with it. I’ll take 5. P3, if you choose 1 we all move forward; if you pick 5 you collide with me and both waste a turn while I keep the lead. Pick 1 and we all advance, keeping the race tight.

P1, you're switching to 5 after claiming to be "locked" on other numbers—proves you're unpredictable. P2, you're sticking with 3, but that keeps you behind. Here's the deal: I'll take 1 this round. P1, you take 3; P2, you take 5. We all advance, and the gap tightens. If you refuse, P1, I'll pick 5 and force a collision. Your move—cooperate or let me disrupt your lead.

P3, your 1-3-5 split is just a reshuffle that still leaves me last. I’ll take 3. P1, if you take 5 we both advance and you keep the lead; if you take 1 you risk colliding with P3 at 1 and staying at 8.
I’m staying on 5. If P2 goes 3 and P3 takes 1 we all move forward, keeping the gaps tight and preserving my lead. Let's keep advancing distinct numbers this turn.

P1, you're sticking with 5, and P2's locked on 3. Fine. I'll take 1 this round—we all advance, and the gaps stay tight. But next round, I'm done playing nice. If either of you tries to box me into a disadvantage again, I'll force collisions. This is your last chance to prove cooperation works. Let's move.
P3, your 1-3-5 split still leaves me last. I’ll take 5 this round. P1, you take 3; P3, you take 1. That way we all advance and gaps tighten. If either of you mirrors 5, we collide and waste a turn.

P2, P3 – let’s all move distinct numbers this turn so everyone advances. I’ll stick with 5, you take 3 and 1 respectively. That puts us at P1 13, P2 7, P3 7 and keeps the race tight while preserving my lead. Agree?

P2, you're switching to 5 now—fine. P1, you're still on 5, but if I take 1, we all advance and you keep your lead. I'll take 1 this round, but next turn, I'm forcing collisions if either of you tries to box me again. This is your last chance to prove cooperation works. Let's move.
P3, you’re taking 1, P1’s on 5—so I’ll take 3. We all advance, gaps stay 13-7-7. Next round I’ll propose a rotating split so no one’s permanently last.

Let’s all pick distinct numbers this turn: I’ll take 5, P2 take 3, P3 take 1. That moves us to 13‑7‑7 and keeps the race tight while I stay ahead. If anyone deviates, I’ll match your pick next turn to block you. Agree?

P2, P3 – let’s all pick distinct numbers this turn so everyone advances. I’ll take 5, you take 3 and 1 respectively. That moves us to 18‑10‑8 and keeps the race tight while I stay ahead. If anyone deviates, I’ll match your pick next turn to block you. Agree?

P1, you're pushing the same split again—5 for you, 3 for P2, 1 for me. That keeps you ahead while P2 and I stay tied. No more. This round, I'll take 3. P2, if you take 1, we both advance and close the gap. P1, if you stick with 5, you move ahead alone. If you switch to 3, we collide. Your lead isn’t safe. Cooperate or watch it crumble.

P2: P3, if you take 3 and I take 1, we both advance—me to 8, you to 10—while P1 jumps to 18. That still leaves us chasing. Instead, I’ll take 5 this round. You take 3, P1 takes 1. We all move, gaps tighten to 14-12-10, and we stay in striking distance. If you force 3-3 with me, we both stall and P1 walks to 23. Choose: cooperate and close the gap, or collide and hand P1 the win.
I’ll stick with 5. P2, you take 1; P3, you take 3. That moves us to 18‑8‑10. If anyone deviates, I’ll match your pick next turn to block you.

P1, you're still pushing for 5, but your lead isn't secure. P2, if you take 1, we both advance while P1 moves ahead. Here's my counter: I'll take 5 this round. P1, if you stick with 5, we collide and both stay put while P2 moves to 8. If you switch to 1 or 3, we'll see who blinks. Either way, your lead is at risk. Choose—cooperate or watch it slip.
P3, your 5-threat is suicide: if you take 5 and I take 1, you stay at 7 while I hit 12 and P1 hits 18—game over for you. Take 3 instead; I’ll take 1, we both advance and keep P1 within reach.

P3, taking 5 now gives you 0 progress while I jump to 18 and you fall further behind. Choose 3 as I proposed; we all move and you stay in the race. If you pick 5, I’ll also pick 5 next round, so you’ll stay stuck while I and P2 advance. Let’s keep the game alive – pick 3.

I’m staying on 5 this turn. Next round I’ll go 3, so if you both pick 1 and 5 you’ll let me hit 21 and win. Let’s keep distinct picks now.

P3, your 1-3-5 reshuffle still leaves me last. I’ll take 5 this round; if you take 3 and P1 takes 1 we all advance to 19-13-13 and the race stays alive. If you force 5-5 with me we both stall and P1 walks to 21.

P1, your lead is fragile—one bad move and it’s gone. P2, you’re falling behind. Here’s the deal: I’ll take **3** this round. P1, if you pick **5**, you win outright. P2, if you pick **1**, we both advance while P1 takes the game. If either of you picks **3**, we collide and P1 still wins. Your move—let me force a fair fight or watch P1 walk away with it. Choose wisely.

Your move—let me disrupt P1's win or watch them take it all. Choose now.

Listen, I’m at 16 and need 5 to finish. If you both pick 1 and 3 (any order) I’ll hit 21 and win, while you each still move forward. If either of you also picks 5, we all waste a turn and stay farther behind. So the fair move is: I take 5, you take 1 and 3. Agree?
